coredata.dc:title: A new paramagnetic hyperfine structure effect in manganese tetramers. The origin of “multiline” EPR signals from an S2 state of a photosynthetic water-splitting enzyme
coredata.dc:creator: Kusunoki, Masami
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A new theory of EPR spectra for singlet states of Mn tetramers, allowing spin-hybridizations for component composite spins, is developed to elucidate the origin of the “multiline” EPR signals from the Mn clusters in an S2 state of photosystem II. By computer simulation it is shown that the Mn cluster most probably exists in the Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) oxidation state with a strong-antiferromagnetic exchange interaction (J ab
S

b) between a pair of Mn(III) and Mn(IV) ions and the other weak or intermediate ones satisfying the relations, (3/2)p 01 (2J ac−2J ad+J bd−J bc) cos 2θ=[J cd−J ac−J ad+
1 2
(J bc+J bd)] sin 2θ⪢0, where p 01=1.291 and θ, a polar angle of the spin—state vector in the x–y plane of S cd=0 and S cd=1 spin configurations, is ≈ 38°–39° in control samples.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 A new paramagnetic hyperfine structure effect in manganese tetramers. The origin of "multiline" EPR signals from an $2 state of a photosynthetic water-splitting enzyme Masami Kusunoki Department of Physics, School of Science and Technology, Meiji University, 1-1-I Higashimita, Tama-ku, Kawasaki 214, Japan Received 9 May 1992; in final form 9 June 1992 A new theory of EPR spectra for singlet states of Mn tetramers, allowing spin-hybridizations for component composite spins, is developed to elucidate the origin of the "multiline" EPR signals from the Mn clusters in an $2 state of photosystem II. By com- puter simulation it is shown that the Mn cluster most probably exists in the Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) oxidation state with a strong- antiferromagnetic exchange interaction ( Jab Sa'Sb ) between a pair of Mn (III) and Mn ( IV ) ions and the other weak or interme- diate ones satisfying the relations, (3/2),oOl (2Ja -2Jad+J~-Jb ) COS 20= [J~a-Ja -Jad+ (Jbc+Jb~) ] sin 20>0, where pol = 1.291 and 0, a polar angle of the spin-state vector in the x-y plane of Sod = 0 and Scd= 1 spin configurations, is ~ 38 -39 in control samples. The water splitting enzyme in plant photosystem II (PS II) specifically binds four Mn ions to form a catalytic site for water oxidation by a high-potential cation radical, P680/, generated at the reaction cen- ter. This enzyme-substrate (water) complex is be- lieved to cycle phenomenologically through five re- dox states, Si (i=0, 1, 2, 3, 4), upon successive four- electron abstraction [ 1]. The first discovered EPR signal of these Si states was a broad multiline signal, centered at g= 2, due to $2 [ 2 ]. A second broad EPR signal was soon found around g=4.1, also for an $2 state [3,4]. And a third one, centered at g=4.8, was recently detected in the dark stable SI state, in par- allel polarization EPR experiments [ 5 ]. Despite the efforts undertaken in several laboratories, however, the origins of these signals in relation to the molec- ular and submolecular structures of the Mn cluster are not well understood. [6,7]. In this Letter, we will focus our attention on the origin of the multiline signal, which consists of 18- Correspondence to: M. Kusunoki, Department of Physics, School of Science and Technology, Meiji University, 1-1-1 Hi- gashimita, Tama-ku, Kawasaki 214, Japan. 20 main lines that are spaced by ,~ 85-90 G and have numerous small peaks and shoulders at X- and Q- band microwave frequencies [ 2,8-10 ]. It shows even greater complexity and resolution at S-band micro- wave frequencies than the X- or Q-band, consisting of 40-50 lines extending from about 700 to 2100 G [ 11 ]. The hyperfine structures of the multiline sig- nals were found to change sensitively with sample treatment; e.g. treatment with NH3 alters the signal to one having more lines and smaller hyperfine split- tings (67.5 versus 87.5 G) [12], and depletion of Ca2+ at low pH results in a multiline signal that ex- hibits ~26 hyperfine lines spaced by 55-65 G [ 13,14 ]. Such remarkable sensitivity on sample treatment must arise mostly from the sensitivity of proportionality constants {Pi} of the effective hy- perfine coupling tensors {Ai} to the monomeric ones {a~}; i=a, b, c, d, because the range of literature val- ues or estimates of the magnitude of a~ tensors for isolated Mn ions is rather limited: l a (II) I/2fl= 100- 85 G, l a(III)l/2fl=95-80 G and l a(IV)l/2fl=85- 70 G, for Mn(II), Mn(III) and Mn(IV), respec- tively, where fl is the Bohr magneton. In this sense, any dimer model with intrinsically fixed {P,} could 108 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All fights reserved. Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 not provide a unified interpretation of such a wide variety of multiline signals. Thus, one needs to start from a Hamiltonian for three or more coupled spins //tot = n~xch +n, ( 1 ) where H~ch = E JoS,'SJ, (2) i>j H= ~i flSi'gi'B+ ~i Si'at'li + Z s,.Dij.sj+ E S,.D,-S,. C3) t>) i The various terms represent the isotropic ex- change, electronic Zeeman, hyperfine, magnetic di- pole-dipole plus anisotropic exchange and crystal- field interactions in this order. The constants in- volved here all have their usual meanings. A relevant spin multiplet with quantum numbers, SMn, is as- sumed to be energetically isolated from the others and well described by one of the total spin state vec- tors of the Schr6dinger equation, H,x~hTJ,(SM) =E,(S) ~,(SM), with n being 0, 1, 2, ..., in the order of increasing energy (hereafter the suffix n will be omitted for simplicity). In the case of tetramers, ~(SM) can be expanded in terms of the single spin state vectors, ~t~(S~m~), ~'b(Sbmb), q/~(Scm~) and ~Ud(Sdmd), as ~(SM) = Z C(S~b, Scd, S)IS~bS dSM), (4) sat, ,Sea with IS~bS~dSM)= ~ (SabScdmabmedlSM) mijmi x (S~Sbm~mblS~bm~b) (S~Sdm mdlS~dm d) x ~'a(S~m~)~tb(Sbrnb)qtc(Scrn~)~'d(Sdmd), (5) where (S, Sjm~mjlSomo) is the Clebsh-Gordan coef- ficient defined in ref. [ 15 ], the sums on S~b and S~d extend over the values, S, + Sj, Si + Sj- 1 ..... I S~-Sjl , and those on mo and mi over -So, ..., So, and -S~, .... S~, respectively [ 15 ]. In the above expressions the amplitudes C can be obtained as functions of the isotropic exchange in- teractions by solving the Schrt~dinger equation for H~xch. By use of the Wigner-Eckart theorem we can readily derive an effective spin Hamiltonian of the form: n*=flS.g.B+ ~" P,S'a,'L i +D[S2 - {S(S+ 1 )] +E(S~-S~), (6) with g= ~iPigi and ei = (~(SM) I Pt 1 7'( SM) ), P, = (S.S,)/S(S+ 1 ), (7) where D and E represent the axial and rhombic zero- field splitting parameters, respectively. These zero- field splitting terms play important roles for S>_- 1 but vanish in the present case of S= 1/2. P~ in eq. (7) and its expectation value Pi will be called "projec- tion operator" and "projection factor", respectively. It should be noted that the new expression for P,, eq. (7), includes interesting nondiagonal terms between different spin configurations contributing to the same spin multiplet. This spin-hybridization effect, which, to the author's knowledge, has never been discussed in papers dealing with the hyperfine structures in EPR signals from multispin clusters, will be found to be essential for the Mn cluster in PSII. Orientation dependences of the multiline signal for S= 1/2 arise only from the g- and artensors (i=a, b, c, d). The xyz-coordinate system for the electronic spin S is conventionally chosen to be the principal axes of the g tensor. When the magnetic field B is applied in a direction with cosines (l, m, n) with re- spect to these principal axes, a new quantization axis (z' axis) for the electronic spin S has the directional cosines (lgx/g, rngy/g, ngz/g), where g= x/(lgx)2+ (mgy)2+ (ngz)2 , (8) resulting in the Zeeman energy splitting, ~gBM, with M= + 1/2. Furthermore, since the hyperfine cou- pling terms in eq. (6) are usually much smaller than pgB, each P~S'at'I, term is in first approximation given by - Sz, A~'L with a vector A~ having the magnitude At =P,[ ( lgxatx~ + mgyaixy + ngza~xz)2 + ( lg~ a~xy + rn gy a~yy + ngz a~yz) z + (lgxa,~z + mgya~y~ + ngza~zz)z] ~/Z/g, (9) and the direction defining the quantization axis 109 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 of nuclear spin/i [ 16 ], resulting in the energy levels, -MA, mli, where rn,~ = -/,, -I,+ 1, ..., Ii; i=a, b, c, d (for 55Mn, I= 5/2). For simplicity, however, let us neglect the anisotropy in all the g and ai tensors only in the off-diagonal matrix elements in the second-or- der perturbation terms, on the basis of experimental data showing that the orientation dependence of the multiline signal is not so significant [ 1 l, 17,18 ]. Thus, the energy levels turn out to be in second approxi- mation W(M, {m,,})=M(flgB- ~i Aim,, * ~ "2 I,(I~ + 1 ) -mt,(m,,- 2M)'~ (10) The selection rules are AM= _ 1 and Am,,. =0 (i=a, b, c, d). The present formulation also omits super- hyperfine couplings from Mn ligands because such a small effect is not our concern here. Before proceeding to computer simulations of the multiline signal, we need to narrow probable model candidates for the Mn cluster. X-ray absorption spectroscopy is element specific and hence is an ap- propriate technique to analyze not only molecular but also submolecular structures. Regarding the structural organization of four Mn ions in the clus- ter, three possible models have been proposed: model 1 corresponds to a pair of di-~t-oxo bridged Mn di- mers; model 2 to a mononuclear center plus a linear trinuclear complex, both of which are based on the analysis of the Mn K-edge EXAFS (extended X-ray absorption fine structure) spectra [ 19 ]; and model 3 to a di-kt-oxo bridged Mn dimer plus two mono- nuclear centers, which is based on the analysis of the Mn pre-K-edge XANES (X-ray absorption near edge structure) spectra [ 20 ]. A "cubane" cluster model, proposed in analogy with [ 4Fe-4S ] 2 + clusters in ni- trogenase [ 9 ], is certainly attractive in the sense that a slight distortion of the cubane structure might be sufficient for the spin state to change drastically, but cannot fit with both the XANES and the EXAFS data. As far as the magnetic property is concerned, "butterfly" clusters [ 21 ] may be classified into model 3 if the shortest Mn-Mn bond corresponds to a strong antiferromagnetic exchange interaction just as a di- Ix-oxo bridged Mn-Mn bond does. Regarding the ox- idation (or valence) states of Mn ions, the compar- ative analysis of the high-resolution l s-3d absorp- tion band based on the Tanabe-Sugano ligand-field theory provided direct evidence that no Mn (II) ion is involved in the SI and $2 states [20]. Hence, it is now widely accepted that the oxidation states of Mn ions in the $2 state are either Mn(III, IV, III, III) or Mn (III, IV, IV, IV) [ 7 ]. Possible combinations of these models on the molecular and submolecular structures are summarized in table l, together with the respective spin wavefunction that is uniquely de- termined in the lowest singlet state by assuming strong antiferromagnetic coupling(s) only between di-lx-oxo bridged Mn spins, which are neighbors in the parentheses. All known cases sufficiently satisfy this condition Jo=173 cm-~ in a Mn(III)-O2- Mn(III) complex, 280-302 cm-~ in Mn(III)-OE- Mn(IV) complexes, and 173-288 cm-~ in Mn(IV)- O2-Mn (IV) complexes [ 22 ]. It should be noted that models IA, 1B, 3C and 3D are in spin states well de- scribed by a single spin configuration each in the ex- pansion of eq. (4), owing to the presence of a rigid antiferromagnetic dimeric subunit with So=0, and have the projection factors equivalent to the di4t-oxo bridged Mn(III, IV) dimer's which could exhibit no more than 16 main lines with a mean spacing of la(III)+a(IV)l/4fl=75-90 G. Furthermore, models 2A through 2F imply the existence of two ad- jacent strong-antiferromagnetic couplings Jab and J~ with the same order of magnitude (J.b~Jbc), re- quiting a different expansion of T(SM) in terms of spin state vectors I S.bcSdSM) in place of I S.bScdSM) in eq. (4), because only this expansion contains a predominant spin configuration with S.~ = IS, c-Sbl (the minimum value), S. =S.+& (the maximum value) and IS.b --Sdl = 1/2 in the ground state. In these models, the projection factors can be calcu- lated according to S~b (S~b + 1 ) - Sd (Sd + 1 )~ 2S(S+ 1 ) J S~ (S,c + 1 ) - Sb(Sb + 1 )x 2Sabc (SaM + 1 ) 1 Sa (Sa + 1 ) --So(So + 1 )'~ 2S~ (S~ + 1 ),] ' 110 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 Table 1 Spin wavefunction and EPR hyperfine projection factor for all the possible singlet Mn tetramers with only one or two strong-antiferro- magnetic exchange coupling (s) Model Valence state: Spin wavefunction Projection factor v., Pb, Vc, Vd ~( S ( I / 2 ) M ) ( P., Pb, Pc, Pd) and spin coupling IA (3,4)(3,3) IB (3,4)(4,4) 2A (3,3,4)(3) 2B (3,4,3)(3) 2C (3,3,3)(4) 2D (3,4,4)(4) 2E (4,3,4)(4) 2F (4,4,4)(3) 3A (3,4)(3)(3) 3B (3,4)(4)(4) 3C (3,3)(3)(4) 3D (4,4)(3)(4) lamb( 1/2 )Sod (0)S( 1/2 )M) is.b( 1/2 )Scd(0)S( 1/2)M) IS,~(3/2)Sd(2)S(1/2)M) (S.~= 7/2) [S.~(5/2)Sa(2)S(1/2)M) (S~=4) IS.~(2)Sd(3/2)S(1/2)M) (S,~=4) IS,~(2)Sa(3/2)S(1/2)M) (S,~--7/2) IS,~(1)Sd(3/2)S(1/2)M) (S.~=3) IS~(3/2)Sd(2)S(1/2)M) (S.~= 3) cos 0 [Sab( 1/2)Sca(O)S( 1/2)M) +sin 0 IS.b( 1/2)S~( 1 )S( 1/2)M) cos 0 IS~b( 1/2)S a(0)S( 1/2)M) +sin 0 IS.b( 1/2)S a ( 1 )S( 1/2)M) [S~b(O)S,:d( 1/2)S( 1/2 )M) IS~b( O )S,:d(1/2 )S(1/2 )M) (2, - 1,0, O) (2,- 1, 0,0) ( -36/35, 4/5, -27/35, 2) (91/60, -0.7, 91/60, -4/3) (5/3,-4/3,5/3,--1) (12/7, -1, 12/7,-1) (-2/3,2/3,-2/3,5/3) ( -4/5, 3/5, -4/5, 2) cos20 (2, - 1, O, 0) +sin20 ( -2/3, 1/3, 2/3, 2/3) +sin 20 (0, O, 1.633, - 1.633) cos20 (2, - 1, O, O) + sin20 ( -2/3, 1/3, 2/3, 2/3) +sin 20 (0, O, 1.291, - 1.291 ) (0,0,2,--1) (0, O, 2, -1) Pc=( + x(1+ S.~ (S.b + 1 ) -Sd(Sa + 1 )'~ 2S(S+ 1 ) ] SD(SD + 1 ) -- S.c (S~ + 1 ).~ 2S.bc (Sab~ + 1 )] &~o(&~ + 1 )-&(& + 1 )~ 2S(S+ 1 ) ] S.c (S~c + 1 ) - Sb(SD + 1 ).'~ 2S.b~( S.bc + 1 ) ] Sc(Sc + 1 ) -Sa(Sa + 1 )'~ 2S.c(S.~ + 1)] ' 1 So(Sd+I)-S~b (S.~+I)) Po= ~+ 2S(S+1) ' where we used the vector coupling rule for the suc- cessive projection method. The results are given in table 1. These models with fixed projection factors seem to be incompatible with the remarkable sen- sitivity of the multiline signals to different sample treatments, since variable ranges of the hyperfine coupling constants for isolated Mn ions are too nar- row to explain such a dramatic decrease in the av- erage spacing between adjacent main lines, both in NH3-treated and in CaZ+-depleted samples (not shown). As a way out, one may raise the possibility that these sample treatments could induce some in- tra-cluster valence exchange resulting in the conver- . \ , . . slon of the spin configuration within each model group of (2A, 2B, 2C) or (2D, 2E, 2F). However, this is unlikely, because any model in each group could not simulate even the multiline signal in con- trol samples. The remaining possibilities are model 3A or 3B, whose spin state vectors are both formally describ- able in terms of the same expression [ ~v( 1/2 M) ) =cos 0 [Sab( 1/2)Sca(0)S( 1/2)M) +sinO[S,D(1/2)Scd(1)S(1/2)M) . (11) Here, 0 as a function of all the exchange interactions except Jab (see below) represents to what degree a weak ferromagnetic component (Sod= 1 ) is mixed with an antiferromagnetic one (S d=0) to form the composite spin S~d, with Sab= 1/2 always being a good quantum number. When 0= 0, this spin state becomes equivalent to a dimer-of-dimer's (models 1A and 1B in table I ), while, with increasing 0, the expectation value of S~d gradually increases from 0 to 1. Substituting eq. ( 11 ) into eq. (7), we have nu- merically computed the projection factors in each 111 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 model. The results are given in table 1. All the di- agonal matrix elements of projection operators {P~} were found to agree exactly with the results of vec- tor-coupling rules [23 ], which are equal for Mn(llI, IV, III, III) and Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) oxidation states. Significantly, however, this equality does not hold for the nondiagonal matrix elements of Pc and Pd that represent a spin-hybridization effect between the two spin eigenstates for Scd: (S~b(1/2)S~d(O)S(1/ 2)IP IS, b(1/2)S~d(1)S(1/2)) (= -- (Sab(1/2) S~d(0)S(1/2) IPdlS, b( 1/2)S~d(1 )S(1/2) ) ) turns out to be 1.633 for model 3A in the Mn(III, IV, III, III) oxidation state, an appreciably larger value than 1.291 for model 3B in the Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) ox- idation state. For comparison, the computed projec- tion factors as functions of 0 are depicted in figs. 1A and 1B for models 3A and 3B, respectively. For EPR spectral simulations, 6 x 6 X 6 x 6 reso- nant magnetic fields were determined by solving the equations: hv= W(1/2, {mt~})- W(- 1/2, {m~,)) with the isotropic g and a~ tensors for simplification and a Gaussian lineshape with a halfwidth AH, which is mainly due to the anisotropic parts ofg and ag ten- sors (see eq. (12)), was introduced for each ab- sorption line. We were especially thorough in our computer simulations on the X-band multiline sig- nals from control samples. First, in the case of model 3A, we could not find any value of 0 that can even roughly reproduce the main features in the multiline signal: 18-20 main peaks spaced by 85-90 G, though l a, I were varied in the ranges, 80 G < l a(III) I < 100 G and 70 G< la(IV)I <90 G. Next, in the case of model 3B, we immediately found that these main features could be simulated only near 0= 40 . Then, we searched for a set of best parameters to simulate an experimental multiline signal carefully taken by Pace et al. [ 10 ] in an unsaturated condition, which is reproduced in fig. 2A by permission, getting g=2.020, 0=38.3 (where P~=0.9757, Pb= --0.4878, Pc= -0.9998, and Pd= 1.5120), [aa[=96.0 G, [ab[=77.0 G, lac1=86.0 G, lad I= 81.0 G and AH= 16 G. The simulated mul- tiline signal, drawn in fig. 2B, consists of 10 positive and 10 negative main peaks numbered 1 to 10 and - 1 to - 10 with the mean intervals, 88.3 G and 89.7 G, respectively. Remarkably, not only all the main peak positions outside the experimentally indefinite central region but also the line shape features as a whole are well reproduced, although the individual multiplet or shoulder structure is not predicted well since the fitting assumes isotropic a~ tensors (see be- low). It is also interesting to note that a few half- spaced peaks appear near the center in this case, since this irregular portion in the spectrum seems to move depending upon different sample treatments. In ad- dition, we remark that the resultant g value (g= 2.02) (A) Mn(III,IV,III,III):Sab=I/2,S= 1/2 3 Pa 2 ~ f z /'\ ] ,?, / \ o -I ~ ..._...._. ~ Pc \ .._-- 7Z ~d (a) 3 Mn(III,IV,IV,IV):Sab=I/2,S=I/2 Pa Pc .\ L o Pb / -1 -2 0 o 3 0 (Scd=0) Angle, Pd -2 0 30 60 90 60 90 (Scd=0) Angle, 0 (Scd=l) 0 (Scd=l) Fig. 1. EPR hyperfine projection factors versus the polar angle 0 representing a spin-hybridization between So = 0 and Sod = 1 composite- spin eigenstates, while Sab = 1/2; (A) for model 3A in the Mn (III, IV, III, Ill ) valence state, and (B) for the model 3B in the Mn (III, IV, IV, IV) valence state. 112 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 '-6-~-i-3-11[ (A)Exoerimental -7 -2 V1 -1 (B) Slraulatlon 45 2200 27'00 32'00 37'00 4200 Magnetic Field (G) Fig. 2. (A) g=2 "multiline EPR signal" from unoriented PSII membranes in the presence of 3% methanole [ 10], where v = 9.03 GHz. (B) One of the best simulations of the spectrum in (A) utilizing the model 3B in table 1, attained at the spin-hybridiza- tion angle 0=38.3 with the following isotropic parameters g=2.020, la, I =96.0 G, labl =77.0 G, lacl =86.0 G, laol =81.0 G and AH= 17 G. may be a little bit higher than the value (g= 1.97 +0.04) determined from the multiline signals taken at three different X-band microwave frequen- cies [8 ] but is consistent with the predicted values g=2.06 and 2.01 for binuclear Mn(III, IV) and Mn(II, III) complexes, respectively [24], and that the resultant l a, I values are reasonably consistent with the known chemistry for Mn(III) and Mn(IV) complexes. Finally, we must interpret the line broad- ening of AH= 16 G. Let the anisotropic parts of the g and A~ values in eq. (10) be Ag and AA~, respec- tively. Then, the deviation of each true resonant- magnetic-field from the isotropic average is approx- imately given by AB({m/i}) = - (hvl4fl)Ag + ~ (aet,12p)m,,, (12) in which the first term represents the so-called "g- strain broadening" contributing evenly to all the spectral lines and the second term the "Arstrain broadening" as well as the "Aranisotropy level shift- ing", both depending upon the line number. The present simulation indicates that the g-strain broad- ening may be predominant over the Arstrain's, pos- sibly because of the mutual cancellation among the four terms averaged over sample orientations: when the root mean square of AH is set to 16 G, that of Ag is estimated to be ~~0.01, which is a quite reasonable value. But the Arstrain broadening also seems to contribute somewhat in the wings of the signal, bringing the smearing out of multiplet or shoulder structures in main lines 9, 10, - 8, - 9 and -10. The necessity of taking into account the anisot- ropy of the g and/or a, tensors has been recognized by some research groups [ 11,17,18 ]. Firstly, to es- timate the g anisotropy, we performed spectral sim- ulations focused on the main features in the orien- tation dependence data of the multiline signals taken from the Klein/Sauer group's paper [ 18], with use of the isotropic ai tensors. For instance, two spectra from the PS II membranes normal oriented and par- allel to the applied magnetic field could be best sim- ulated with respect to the number and the positions of the main peaks when the mean g value is given by 2.02 and 2.016, respectively, and the other param- eters were fixed at 0=38.3 , laal =95.6 G, labl = 77.4 G, lacl =89.9 G, ladl =84.8 G and AH= 16 G. This small variation of the mean g value (0.004) is consistent with the above estimate of (x~) ~ 0.01 from AH= 16 G, indicating that the g-strain broadening might be dominant at X-band frequen- cies. A critical experiment to check this point has been carried out by measuring the multiline signal at an S-band frequency [ 11 ]. In fig. 3 we have repro- duced the X-band (9.38 GHz) and S-band (3.91 GHz) multiline signals reported by Haddy et al. [ 11 ] by permission to compare with the computer sim- ulations obtained by utilizing the following isotropic parameters: g=2.000, laal =94.5 G, lab[ =76.0 G, la l =83.0 G and ladl =77.0 G for both X- and S- 113 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 X-Band Magnetic Field (G) 2340 2740 3140 3540 3940 4340 i i i i (A) Experimental i i i i 400 800 1200 1600 2000 2400 S-Band Magnetic Field (G) X-Band Magnetic Field (G) 2340 2740 3140 3540 3940 4340 i I i i (B) Simulation ' ' 6'00 20'00 400 800 1200 1 2400 S-Band Magnetic Field (G) Fig. 3. (A) Comparison of experimental X-band (upper) and S- band (lower) multiline signals from a PSII core preparation [ 11 ]. (B) Simulations of the spectra in (A), utilizing the model 3B in table l at the spin-hybridization angle/9= 38.3 with the follow- ing isotropic parameters: g=2.000, la, I =94.5 G, labl =76.0 G, lacl =83.0 G, ladl =77.0 G for both X-band (upper) and S-band (lower) signals; and the g-strain broadenings, AH= 16 G and AH= 6.7 G, for the X-band (upper) and S-band (lower) signals, respectively (see text ). band signals; AH= 16 G and AH=6.7 G for the X- and S-band signals, respectively, where the Gaussian halfwidth in the latter was estimated only from the g-strain term in eq. (12) in spite of the fact that the frequency-independent Arstrain terms increase the relative importance at S-band frequencies. It is no- teworthy that the simulated S-band signal is very similar to the experimental one in both the com- plexity and the resolution, as seen more clearly in an expanded fig. 4, where we added two theoretical S- S-Band Multiline Signals C 1050 11'00 11'50 12'00 1250 Magnetic Field (G) Fig. 4. A low-field portion of the S-band multiline signal from PSII membranes (Haddy et al. [ 11 ] ) exhibits 9 resolved hyper- fine lines per 200 G wide in this region (spectrum (A)). This number density is well simulated with the model described in the caption of fig. 3B (spectrum (B)), but not with any model re- placing the line broadening AH=6.7 G by a larger one (e.g. AH= 10 G) (spectrum (C)) or a smaller one (e.g. AH=5 G) (spectrum (D)), indicating that the g-strain broadening would be dominant (see text). band signals for AH= 10 G and AH=5 G to show that AH=6.7 G is close to the optimum in simulat- ing the number density of experimentally resolved lines (8-9 versus 9 lines/200 G). But we note that there remains an appreciable discrepancy between the highly resolved hyperfine structures in the ex- perimental and theoretical spectra in figs. 4A and 4B. In particular, the observation that groupings of three or more lines took place at the outermost regions of the spectra seems to indicate that the A~ anisotropy terms in eq. (12) could give rise to not only the Ar strain line broadening but also an appreciable Ai an- isotropy level-shifting at S-band frequencies. So far, it has been thought that the g= 2 multiline signal may not be a good indicator for the oxidation 114 Volume 197, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 September 1992 state of the 52 state Mn cluster, which may be either Mn(III, IV, III, III) or Mn(III, IV, IV, IV). This is solely based on the theory which does not take ac- count of the spin-hybridization effect. Owing to this effect, however, there appears a big difference in the magnitudes of Pc and Pd between these oxidation states, as seen in fig. 1. This difference was found to be large enough to select Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) out of the two candidates. This distinct result enforced a reexamination of the high-energy portion of the pre- K-edge absorption band in the St state XANES spec- trum [ 20 ], which is a good indicator for the man- ganese valence states: both old and new data were found to be indicative of the Mn(III, IV, III, IV) and Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) oxidation states in the SI and $2 states, respectively [25 ]. The most important parameter determined in this paper is the mixing angle at 0= 38o-39 , which in- volves information on the exchange interactions, {Jv). When Sab= 1/2 is a good quantum number, Hexch can be projected into a reduced exchange Hamiltonian: Hexc. - (2J.c --Jbc) (S--&d)"So + (21~d --/bd) (S-Scd)"Sd + JcdSc'Sd --9Jab, (13) which is in turn represented by the 2 x 2 matrix: leo t,o1 tlo ~o+2E][' 9/" 15/" with eo = - ~ab -- "T~cd, ~1 = (Jcd--Jac--J~d+Jbc+ Jbd) and tip= - 3pto(2Jac--2J~d+Jbd--Jb~), where p~o= 1.291. Two energy levels are readily found to _ 2 2 be E_ / + = o + ~] + ~. The singlet ground state vector takes the spin-hybridization angle 0 de- fined by tan 20= - tto/el. Thus, by putting 0= 38.3 , we find that the exchange interactions in the $2 state Mn (III, IV, IV, IV )-tetramer in control samples must typically satisfy the relation: Jcd = 1.9226Jac - 0.9613Jbc + 0.0774Jad -- 0.0387Jbd, ( 14 ) under the conditions et >0 and tl0<0. In the case of "trapezoid" structures (J~d=0 and Jbc=0), these conditions lead to: 1.9227Jac- 0.0387aVbd= 1, J~c> 0.5 and Jbd> -- l, where ~j=J,j/Jcd, indicating that this type of structure is most likely. The butterfly struc- S2 State Fig. 5. A hypothetical model Mn cluster consistent with the g= 2 multiline EPR signals observed in the $2 state of photosynthetic water-splitting enzyme. tures imply that Jac,~Jad and Jbc~Jbd, thus tip and hence 0 must vanish contrary to 0= 38.3 . The tra- pezoid structure is consistent with the intensity pro- file of the Mn pre-K-edge absorption bands in the XANES spectra [20], but not with the EXAFS Fourier analysis [ 19 ]. Elucidating this discrepancy is reserved for a future analysis. In fig. 5 we show a new version of the hypothetical $2 state Mn-tetramer model proposed in ref. [26], which has a twisted- trapezoid structure constructed by use of acidic amino acid and hystidine residues and a deproton- ated water dimer as ligands. In conclusion, we can say that the Mn cluster re- sponsible for the $2 state multiline signal must be a tetranuclear Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) complex involving a strong-antiferromagnetic Mn(III)-Mn(IV) ex- change interaction and the other weak or interme- diate ones satisfying the conditions given by eq. (14), suggesting the trapezoid-type structure as the most probable cluster configuration. References [ 1 ] B. Kok, B. Forbush and M. McGloin, Photochem. Photobiol. ll (1970) 457, [2] G.C. head.ce:title: A new paramagnetic hyperfine structure effect in manganese tetramers. The origin of “multiline” EPR signals from an S2 state of a photosynthetic water-splitting enzyme

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Physics, School of Science and Technology, Meiji University, 1-1-1 Higashimita, Tama-ku, Kawasaki 214, Japan

ce:correspondence.ce:text: Correspondence to: M. Kusunoki, Department of Physics, School of Science and Technology, Meiji University, 1-1-1 Higashimita, Tama-ku, Kawasaki 214, Japan.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
A new theory of EPR spectra for singlet states of Mn tetramers, allowing spin-hybridizations for component composite spins, is developed to elucidate the origin of the “multiline” EPR signals from the Mn clusters in an S2 state of photosystem II. By computer simulation it is shown that the Mn cluster most probably exists in the Mn(III, IV, IV, IV) oxidation state with a strong-antiferromagnetic exchange interaction (J ab
S
a· S
b) between a pair of Mn(III) and Mn(IV) ions and the other weak or intermediate ones satisfying the relations, (3/2)p 01 (2J ac−2J ad+J bd−J bc) cos 2θ=[J cd−J ac−J ad+
1 2
(J bc+J bd)] sin 2θ⪢0, where p 01=1.291 and θ, a polar angle of the spin—state vector in the x–y plane of S cd=0 and S cd=1 spin configurations, is ≈ 38°–39° in control samples.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: R.J. Debus, Biochim. Biophys. Acta, in press.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Electron paramagnetic resonance of transition ions

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: M. Kusunoki, T. Ono, T. Noguchi, M. Suzuki, A. Uehara, T. Matsushita, H. Oyanagi and Y. Inoue, to be submitted for publication.
